importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication highlights the urgency of the food stamp program shutdown during the federal government shutdown, which is currently ongoing and impacting critical social programs.

The federal government shutdown began on October 1, 2025, directly leading to the financial crisis in key federal assistance programs like SNAP and WIC, which are now unable to issue full benefits in November.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The food stamp program is expected to run out of funds in two weeks, with full benefits at risk for November 2025, placing millions of Americans at risk of losing access to food assistance.

keyTakeAways: 42 million Americans are at risk of losing food stamp benefits in November due to the federal government shutdown.
The USDA has stated that full payment of SNAP benefits will not be possible in November without emergency funding.
The food stamp program is one of the nation’s largest anti-hunger programs, providing an average monthly benefit of $188 per person.
The Trump administration has not committed to funding SNAP, unlike its actions for WIC, which received a $300 million infusion from tariff revenue.
17 states have halted new food stamp applications due to technical constraints in their systems that require partial payments during the transition period.
Democrats and critics of the administration argue that Republicans are prioritizing political agendas over food security and vulnerable families.
A $6 billion contingency fund exists, but it is insufficient to cover the $8 billion needed for November benefits.
The shutdown has triggered a national debate on whether the federal government should prioritize social safety net programs during a funding gap.
WIC, another nutrition program, was temporarily protected by a $300 million tariff revenue transfer, but that funding cannot be used for SNAP.
Experts stress that food pantries are already overwhelmed and cannot fill the gap left by the SNAP lapse, especially with Thanksgiving approaching.

namedEntities.name: Brooke Rollins
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She announced that the food stamp program will run out of money in two weeks and blamed Democrats for the shutdown, making her a central figure in the administration’s response.

namedEntities.name: Kathy Hochul
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She criticized the Trump administration for halting food stamp payments, calling it a deliberate and harmful action that harms vulnerable families.

namedEntities.name: Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is at risk of running out of funds in November, affecting millions of low-income Americans and representing the second major nutrition program impacted by the shutdown.

namedEntities.name: WIC
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Federal nutrition program for pregnant women, new moms, and young children
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: WIC is also under funding pressure, though it was temporarily protected by a $300 million tariff revenue infusion, highlighting the broader crisis in federal nutrition programs.

namedEntities.name: Trump administration
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Federal executive branch under President Donald Trump
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The administration is at the center of the debate over funding for food assistance, with claims that it prioritized political agendas over food security and refused to fund SNAP despite prior actions for WIC.

namedEntities.name: Democrats
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They argue that Republicans are refusing to negotiate a spending deal that includes extended Obamacare subsidies, contributing to the shutdown and the lack of funding for food assistance.

namedEntities.name: Obamacare premium subsidies
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Health insurance subsidies under the Affordable Care Act
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Democrats argue that the Republican refusal to extend these subsidies is a key reason for the government shutdown and the funding crisis in social programs.

namedEntities.name: Tariff revenue
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A $300 million transfer from tariff revenue was used to sustain WIC, but not enough to fund SNAP, illustrating a lack of equitable funding across nutrition programs.

namedEntities.name: Food Research & Action Center
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The group emphasizes that SNAP is critical for food security, especially with Thanksgiving approaching, and calls for urgent federal action.

namedEntities.name: Center on Budget and Policy Priorities
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The organization urges the administration to protect food stamp benefits, citing previous precedent where other programs were supported during shutdowns.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Roughly 42 million Americans are at risk of losing food stamp benefits in November due to the ongoing federal government shutdown, with the U.S. Department of Agriculture warning that the program will run out of funds in two weeks. The Trump administration has not committed to funding SNAP, unlike its use of tariff revenue to sustain WIC, and has blamed Democrats for the political impasse. While a $6 billion contingency fund exists, it is insufficient to cover the $8 billion needed for November payments. As a result, 17 states have paused new food stamp applications, and experts warn that food pantries are already overwhelmed. This crisis is part of a broader national debate over whether political priorities should override critical social safety net programs, especially with Thanksgiving approaching. Advocacy groups and state leaders are calling for urgent intervention to prevent vulnerable families from going hungry.
title: Millions of Americans at Risk of Losing Food Stamps Next Month Amid Shutdown
